[DI28984] Danville Register, Danville, VA 6/20/1976

Johnson Youth Dies at Age 9

Gretna- Milton Lee Johnson, son of William Poyse (Billy) and Emma Jean Nuckols Johnson of Gretna Rt 2 died last night in Virginia Baptist Hospital after a short illness. He completed the 3rd grade at Mt Airy Elementary School this year. He was a member of St Andrews United Methodist Church. IN addition to his parents he is survived by a brother, W Poyse Johnson II; a sister Martha Ann and a maternal grandmother Mrs Christine O Nuckols, Chatham Rt 6. The body is at Colbert-Moran Funeral Home pending completion of final arrangements.

[NI29000] Bluefield Daily Telegraph Jan 29,2008

Polly Moore Whitley Hagy, age 96, of Richlands, Va., formerly of Tazewell, died Monday, January 28, 2008. Born in North Tazewell, Va., she was the daughter of the late Wesley Price Whitley and Catherine (Kate) Lawrence Whitley, both Tazewell natives. Mrs. Hagy was a well respected educator and guidance counselor with the latter part of her career being served at Tazewell High School. She worked in the Tazewell County School System from 1945 until her retirement in 1977. Mrs. Hagy is fondly remembered by her former students, fellow teachers, and colleagues as a devoted educator with a love for reading that she instilled in others. She earned her BS and Master's degrees from Radford College with continued education throughout her career.

A lifelong resident of Tazewell County, she was active in both church and civic affairs and served as president of several clubs: Delta Kappa Gamma, an organization for outstanding women educators (a member since 1952), Tazewell Literary Club, American Association of University Women, and the PTA. She was active in the Tazewell Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) and the First Christian Church (Disciples of Christ) Richlands. Church work was an important part of "Miss Polly's" life. She taught Sunday school and led Bible study and was active in women's work. She served as an elder in the Tazewell Christian Church and a deaconess emeritus in the Richlands First Christian Church. She was preceded in death by her husband, Rufus Glen Hagy; an infant son, Rufus Glen (R.G.) Jr.; a brother, William Allen (Bill) Whitley and his wife, Grace; brother-in-law,«u»«b» Rex Leslie Nuckolls«/u»«/b»; and son-in-law, Dr. Emerson Lynn Kirby Sr. Survivors include her sister, Mary Price Nuckolls of Richlands; three children: Daughter, Patricia (Pat) Price Hagy Kirby with whom she had made her home since the death of her husband; and sons, Roger Glen Hagy and his wife Louise of Landrum, S.C., and Dr. John Albert Hagy Sr. and his wife Carol of Rocky Mount, Va. She was blessed with 13 grandchildren and 26 great-grandchildren. Her special caregivers since 2002: Rachel Clifton, Mary Sparks, Darlene Osborne, Orpha Mullins and Lisa Miller.The Reverend Stafford Compton will be officiating a memorial service celebrating Mrs. Hagy's life in the sanctuary of the First Christian Church (DOC) in Richlands, Va. on Wednesday, January 30, 2008 at 2:00 p.m. followed by visitation and gathering of love in the church fellowship hall.In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Christian Women's Fellowship (CWF) of the First Christian Church in Richlands, P.O. Box 1307, Richlands, VA 24641 or the CWF of the Tazewell Christian Church in Tazewell, 302 East Pine Street, Tazewell, VA 24651. Online condolences may be sent to the family by going to www.SingletonFuneralService.com.

Singleton Funeral Service of Cedar Bluff, Va. is serving the Hagy family.

[DI29000] Bland Virginia News April 10 2008

Mary Price Nuckolls, 95, of Richlands, died April 5 at her home following a lengthy illness.

Born in Tazewell County, she was the daughter of the late Wesley and Mary Catherine Lawrence Whitley, both Tazewell County natives. She had made her home in the Richlands area most of her life and was a member of the Richlands Presbyterian Church and a past Matron of the Order of the Eastern Star #104 of Richlands. She was a graduate of Tazewell High School Class of 1930. In addition to her parents, she was preceded in death by her husband,«u»«b» R. Leslie "Les" Nuckolls;«/u»«/b» one sister, Polly Hagy; and one brother, William Whitley. She was the last surviving member of her immediate family. Survivors: daughters, Katsy Lawson and husband, Frank, of Richlands, Rev. Ann Blackburn of Cleveland, Tenn., Susie Boothe of Richlands; seven grandchildren; seven great grandchildren; and special caregivers, Sharon Stillwell, Wanda Carver, Frances Horn, and Neal Ann Allison. At the request of Mrs. Nuckolls, a graveside service was conducted April 7 at 11 a.m. at the Greenhills Memory Gardens Mausoleum at Claypool Hill with the Rev. Ann Blackburn officiating. Interment followed.

As were her wishes, there was no visitation at the funeral home. In lieu of flowers, gifts of remembrance may be made to Preferred Hospice, 2629 Front Street, Richlands, VA 24641.

Hurst-Scott Funeral Home in Richlands was in charge of arrangements.(SSDI 12/23/1912 issued VA)

[DI29001] Richland News Press 6/10//2009

Ms. Leslie Sue Boothe, age 65, of Richlands, Va., passed away Sat., June 6, 2009 at her home following a brief illness.

She was born in Tazewell County and was the daughter of the late Les and Mary Price Nuckolls. She had made her home in the Richlands, Va., area most of her life and was a customer service representative for Wal-Mart for the past 18 years. She was a member and former secretary for the First United Methodist Church in Richlands, Va., and was a graduate of Richlands High School Class of 1961.Survivors are: one daughter: Leslea Caschette and husband, Christopher, of Pittsford, N.Y.; one son: Chuck Boothe and wife, Derondah, of Bluefield, Va.; two sisters: Ann Blackburn of Cleveland, Tenn., Katsy Lawson and husband, Frank, of Richlands, Va.; four grandchildren, Savannah Boothe, Willa Boothe, Olivia Caschette, and Lorelei Caschette also survive.

Friends called Tues., June 9, 2009 from 5:00 p.m. until 7:30 p.m. at the Hurst-Scott Funeral Home in Richlands, Va. Memorial services were private. Hurst-Scott Funeral Home in Richlands, Va., was in charge of arrangements

[BI29061] Post-Herald | Beckley, West Virginia | Thursday, June 19, 1952 | Page 3

Pfc and Mrs Harold Knuckles announce the birth of their first child born at Raleigh Gen Hops Sunday morning. The 8 lb 13 ounce boy has been named Gary Wayne. Mrs Knuckles is the former barbara Richmond of Beckley and is residing at 102 Bailey Ave.The father is stationed in Austria with the United States Army

Raleigh Register Wed 2/25/1953 has photo

Gary Wayne Knuckles, son of Pfc Harold E Knuckles who was born June 15 soon after his father had been sent to Camp Saalfelden Austria to serve with the U S Army. Gary is shown here with his mother, the former Miss barbara Richmond. Mrs Knuckles is the daughter of Mrs Dottie Richmond, baily Ave. Pfc Knuckles is the son of Mr and Mrs Howard Kncukles, Beckley. Gary Wayne and his GI father expect to get together shortly before the little lad observes his first birthday. Mrs Knuckles says she expects her husband home late in May.

[DI29101] Abilene Reporter, Wednesday, Jan 1, 1992 Pg 5D Col1

John David Nuckolls

Graveside services for John David Nuckolls, 70, of 3665 Varisty, will be at 1 p.m. Thursday in Cedar Hill Cemetery with H B Terry Jr officiating, directed by Elliott-Hamil Funeral Home, 542 Hickory. He died Monday at a local hospital. Mr Nuckolls was born in Newport Arkansas and moved from Phoenix Arizona to Abilene in 1990. He attended school in Newport. He was an elevator mechanic for Otis Elevator Company in Phoenix for 20 years. He was a US Army Air Corps Veteran of WWII and a member of Veterans of Foreign Wars. He was a Baptist, a member of the Masonic Lodge and the widower of Ora Steen Nuckolls. Survivors include four daughters, Deborah Carlow of Abilene and Sandra Nuckolls, Patricia Dapp and Brenda Atherton, all of Phoenix; a son, Jerry Nuckolls of Abilene; nine grandchildren and four great grandchildren.

[HI29128] (Research):Parentage not proven. I used the preponderance of the evidence of the census that he was in fact related to Lienne Nuckles Green and her mother, as her lived with them in 1910. The Mary Nuckles in the census with Robert and Lienne Green said she had 4 children and 4 were living.

This leads me to believe that the Mollie that William married in 1886 was actually the mother of the children born earlier found in the 1880 census and perhaps they did not officially marry until 1886. See census records for connections. Given William divorced Mollie and remarried suggest the children lived seperately, as the census indeed show. I eliminated the other sons of Sameul Reed Nuckles because they all named a son Albert, and William was the only left to continue the naming pattern

[NI29279] (Source janetgbaker@islc.net)

Biographical Sketch Of Willaim Isham Irby, Sr.

Feb. 1, 1934 , As told to family friend G. A. Charter heslop, at the age of 82.

William Isham Irby, Sr., son of William Rufus Irby and Maria Massie (Gentry) Irby, was born on his father's 656 acre farm at Locust Hill, four miles above Rockville, Va., Hanover County, on Feb. 23, 1851. He received his early education from his mother and several older sisters. His first formal schooling was at Capt. Tarlton Woodson's academy in Hanover County. He attended Changler & Coleman's Bowling Green Academy in 1867-68, returning to Locust Hill when he completed his course.

On January 10, 1873 he went to Hawkes Nest, West Virginia to clerk for MacDonald & Rudisill, ballast contractors for the Chesapeake & Ohio Railroad, remaining until June, 1873 when he again returned to the farm. On March 20, 1875 he entered the telegraph office of the C. & O. at Hanover Courthouse and clerked under James Benson. He showed an aptitude for the work and when Benson left to attend the Philadelphia Centennial Exposition on May 1876, young Irby was placed in charge of the office. During his stay there he was also a deputy tax collector for the County under Treasurer George Doswell and studied under the office of Edmund Waddell, county court clerk.

In the fall of 1876, he was engaged to teach in the public school at Manakin, Va., serving there two years. In 1878 he entered Randolph-Macon College, Ashland, Va., being a classmate of the future Secretary of the Navy and State Senator, Claude Swanson. Ill health forced him to withdraw, however, and he returned to his home at Locust Hill. William's father, Captain William Rufus Irby, died June 2, 1879, and William took charge of the farm He opened a small store at what is now Vontay, two miles above the farm of Arthur Brown. He remained until December, 1887.

On Sept. 29, 1886, he was married to Susan Elizabeth Nuckolls of Waldrop, Louisa County, daughter of Charles Yancey and Victoria Anderson (Walton) Nuckolls. William met his bride about a year before while she was teaching school in his neighborhood (at his sister's Mrs. Gray). Susan was 13 years his junior, being born June 11, 1864. Susan Irby's mother, Maria Massie Irby, died July 29, 1887, and is buried beside her husband in the family plot on the Locust Hill farm. THeir first child, Charles Rufus Irby, was born August 2, 1887, and in December the young couple moved to Mrs. Irby's old home at Melrose, Louisa County, one mile from Thompson's Crossroads. In 1888 he opened a wholesale and retail general merchandise store at what is now Mechansville, Va. five miles south of Gordonsville, Va. During this time he conducted a school at his home for his children and a few outsiders.

To complete the education of his children he sent his family to Washington, D.C., in 1906. In 1908 (Feb. 12th). he sold his business and came to Washington, D.C. to join them. William was baptised in the Christian Church when he was 17 years old.

[NI29340] Mentoned in her sisters obituary 2009

Obituary Date: 7 Aug 2009 Newspaper Title: Herald-Star Newspaper Location: Steubenville, OH, USA

KISER, Garnet Marie, 95, departed this life on August 5, 2009, in Steubenville, Ohio.

She was born April 26, 1914, in Monarch, West Virginia (Kanawha County), to the late Lester W. Moore and Emma Lou (Boyd) Moore.

In addition to her parents, Garnet Marie was preceded in death by three husbands, Frank J. Combs, Roscoe E. Betts and Cline C. Kiser. She was the mother of Peggy Marie Combs who died in infancy in 1934. She was also preceded in death by sisters, Norma Ann Moore, Edith Patton, Dana «b»Nuckles«/b», Bertha Hughes and Olive Upton.

She is survived by her son, James F. Combs and his wife, Carol June of Wintersville, Ohio; daughter, Jean Ann Johnson of St. Albans, West Virginia. Also surviving include grandchildren, Diane C. Combs, David A. Combs, Susan Summers Barnes, Robert Summers and Leigh Ann Summers Thompson; great-grandchildren, Roger Summers, Sean Summers and Samanthia Thompson. Two sisters survive her, Ethel Hinkle of Richwood, West Virginia, and June Ferrell of St. Augustine, Florida.

Garnet Marie was a resident of Kanawha County, West Virginia, for 48 years. She was baptized into Christ October 18, 1956. She was a member of the Shrewsbury Church of Christ until she moved to Lebanon, Virginia in 1963. She was an active member in the Lebanon Church of Christ until her removal to Steubenville, Ohio in 1995 where she was affiliated with the Lovers Lane Church of Christ.

Garnet Marie was very talented. Her talent and creativity took her in many directions. While in East Bank, West Virginia, she and her husband, Frank owned and operated The Combs Upholstery Shop. While working the shop Garnet Marie selected the materials and fabrics and sewed and upholstered couches, chairs and automobile interiors.

While a resident of Russell County, Virginia, Garnet Marie worked at various jobs outside the home. She was manager and clerk in a small family owned grocery store. She worked as a seamstress in a garment factory and was a food and nutrition representative for a short time.

Her home exemplified her talent as an artist through her eye for color and detail. Her most outstanding talent was her ability to play piano. She was self-taught and could play all types of music: ragtime, polka, country, classical and religious.

In recent years she has entertained residents and friends at The Martha Manor Home and the Carriage Inn in Steubenville, Ohio. Sitting at the piano, you would hear her say, "name that tune". Someone would name a song and she would play it. Music just seemed to flow from her fingers. Her wit was not exceeded. One would ask, "Can you play, 'Somewhere Over The Rainbow'?" and she would come back with, "I can't play over the rainbow but I will play for you here." She made life a little brighter for us all with her sunshine. She will be long remembered.

Friends may call at Montgomery Memorial Park, London, West Virginia, in the chapel on Monday, August 10, 2009, from 12:30 p.m. until time of service at 1:30 p.m. with Minister Lloyd N. Gwinn officiating.

In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to: Martha Manor Home, 408 N. 5th Street, Steubenville, OH 43952, Carriage Inn of Steubenville Activities Assoc., 3102 St. Charles Dr., Steubenville, OH 43952 or the Alzheimer's Association.

[DI29453] Daily Independent, The (Ashland, KY) - January 3, 2010

Deceased Name: Clarence Edward Nuckels Jr.

Date of death: 12/15/2009 Date of birth: 01/29/1925

Clarence Edward Nuckels Jr., known to friends and family as Bud, passed away during the dawn hours of Tuesday, Dec. 15, 2009, in Florence, Ala. Bud was born in Ludlow, Ky. on Jan. 29, 1925. Dying just shy of his 85th birthday, he had just reached half a century as a Mason.

Bud met his sweetheart, Ruth Lavern Hall, born April 13, 1926, while in school in Ludlow, Ky. in 1939 and despite a stint away in the Navy during WWII, managed to pursue her until they were married during the summer of 1947. He started at Purdue University in the fall of 47 on the G.I. bill and graduated with a degree in Electrical Engineering.

Bud used his new skills to be one of two engineers to first track the Sputnik satellite in 1957 while on assignment at Eglin Air Force Base on the Florida panhandle. Later, while working for Pan American World Airways during the 1960s, he was often on loan around the world to NASA, the Department of Defense and the Air Force as he worked on tracking the Mercury, Gemini and Apollo space programs, including the moon landing in 1969. During the 1970s, Bud worked continuously overseas with his expatriate family in tow, running the airport in Liberia, West Africa and installing navigation systems in the Sultanate of Oman, located on the Saudi Arabian peninsula.

Returning stateside during the 1980s, he worked until PanAm folded in 1991. Bud tried to retire several times during the 1990s, once to the Ashville area of N.C., then again to Hot Springs Village, Ark., but kept being called back to work as a consultant until he finally managed to settle in Florence, Ala. in 2003, where he and his wife of then 56 years joined his youngest son, Todd, daughter-in-law, Dr. Barbara Frazier, and their three children, Sam, Christopher and William. In addition, left behind are his middle son, Mark, with granddaughter Anna; daugther-in-law, Nancy, with granddaughter Kendra and his brother John, with sister-in-law Valerie, niece Andrea and nephew Craig.

All told his wife counts some 62 years of marriage and 23 moves, not including the rentals, but what are a few here or there amongst such long devoted friends. All that knew Bud shall now have to content themselves with the thought of one day seeing him again on the other side.
